entries.meaning: comparative form of duff: more duff
(informal) An incompetent, indolent, or clumsy person.
(sports) A player having little skill, especially a golfer who duffs.
(archaic) A pedlar or hawker, especially one selling cheap or substandard goods.
(archaic) Cheap or substandard goods sold by a duffer.
A cow that does not produce milk.
examples: We have some good cows in this State, but, unfortunately, we have too many duffer cows that are not only being fed and milked at a loss hut are eating up a portion of the profit of the good cow which is being milked alongside them.

entries.meaning: (Australia, dated) A cattle thief or thief of other livestock; one who alters the brands of cattle.
examples: The cattle dufferâ€²s escape would have been impeded by those young ones. Calves can be unruly unless you move them carefully in the company of their mothers.

entries.meaning: A racing pigeon that does not perform well.
(entomology) Any of various nymphalid butterflies of the genus Discophora.
